body.p: In “The Lower Nasal Base: An Anatomical Study,” Dr Daniel and his coauthors undertook the dissection of 45 cadaver noses to fully appreciate the anatomy of the lower nasal base. This is an often neglected and not fully understood anatomical region 1,2 consisting of the columellar base, nostril sills, and alar lobules. Their dissections are simply some of the best that our readers will ever see.

The authors begin by clearing up some common misconceptions: (a) there is, in fact, a distinct lower nasal base consisting of the columellar base, nostril sills, and alar lobules; (b) the medial border of the levator labii superioris alaeque nasalis (LLSAN) becomes the defining muscle of the alar crease; (c) more than 1 muscle depresses the nasal tip (eg, the LLSAN), although the depressor septi nasalis (DSN) is usually attributed to be the only muscle responsible for that; (d) the transverse line or fold that occurs on forceful smiling represents the junction between 2 components of the orbicularis; and (e) the entire alar lobule is actually devoid of cartilage.

The authors also clarify some debatable issues, including the idea that the DSN is a paired muscle that originates from the maxilla just above the medial incisor and the concept that Pitanguy’s ligament is not a true dermocartilaginous ligament because if it were, it would contradict the 5-layer laminate concept of the nasal soft tissue envelope. 3 Their video gives a nice demonstration of the distinct tether that allows the tip to be pulled down by muscular contracture, an action that involves this ligament. More important, the authors establish that one can resolve the problem of the plunging tip by interrupting the continuity of the fibromuscular structure (from the DSN to the deep portion of Pitanguy’s midline ligament) at either end. Personally, we find it easiest to correct tip depression by approaching the DSN from a transverse incision at the frenulum.

The speculation of the authors that botulinum toxin injections delivered to some of the muscles of the lower nasal base may be beneficial is well supported by clinical evidence. Sucupira and Abramovitz 4 reported dramatic results with botulinum toxin injections to the LLSAN to treat the gummy smile; Dayan and Kempiners 5 injected the DSN and LLSAN to correct tip ptosis and the gummy smile. Radaelli 6 also used botulinum toxin to treat tip ptosis. A frequent complaint of patients is that the nasal base widens on broad smiling. Redaelli and Braccini 7 demonstrated a narrower interalar distance after botulinum toxin treatment to the LLSAN, but the narrow alae also caused a narrower smile, which not all patients want. Although the horizontal position of the ala can be prevented from drifting superiorly, 5 its width is not reduced by the injections. Ghavami et al 8 understandably warned that it is difficult to inject the LLSAN and DPN, suggesting that botulinum toxin for that particular purpose may not be the ultimate treatment. We, too, are concerned about the risk to the natural smile from these injections.

The authors describe the morphology of the lower nasal base in detail and with much accuracy, noting that the nostril-sill junction is not always distinct. It is also possible that it varies considerably from one ethnic group to another, as do other parts of the nasal morphology. 9 We agree and find it to be a frustrating problem because the surgeon ideally wants the incision for alar base (or sill) excisions to be made in that junction. We have noticed that the junction can almost always be located by pressing on the alar rim with an index finger. Even if the nostril and sill look like one continuous rolled structure, the nostril tends to bend at the nostril-sill junction (Figure 1). This is because the sill has a more anterior/posterior direction than the alar rim, and the sill is relatively fixed to the lip. Therefore, the ala tends to fold at that junction. Scars, in our experience, tend to be more inconspicuous at the nostril-sill junction and minimize the need for the small flap that has been suggested to camouflage scars following alar base excisions. 10

caption.p: (A) As Daniel et al correctly note, the ala and sill often blend into 1 structure with a rolled border, making it difficult to tell on front view where the ala/sill junction is located. (B) Fortunately, the sill usually has a more anterior/posterior direction than that of the ala and is fixed to the lip. (C) Consequently, pressing on the ala with a finger causes the ala to fold at the ala/sill junction. Incisions at this junction when performing alar base or sill excision leave the most inconspicuous scar.

body.p:
In discussing the surgical relevance of the lower nasal base, the authors raise an important question about how to narrow the columellar base. Guyuron 11 has found success in direct soft tissue excision between the footplates. Indirectly, those procedures that reduce the overall nasal base (eg, “cinch procedures” 12
-16 ) also narrow the columellar base to some extent. Actual alar release from the pyriform aperture 17 helps prevent recurrence of the broad nasal base following “cinch” procedures. For example, when a Joseph elevator penetrates the buccal sulcus to sweep the tissues off the rim of the pyriform aperture, the ala becomes quite flaccid, permitting an interalar suture to hold the alae in a much more medial location and under less tension than would be the case otherwise (Figure 2). Of interest, therefore, is which lower nasal base structures are actually released when alar release is performed. In a study involving the senior author of this Commentary (RPG), 18 it appeared that the pyriform ligament (a type of “fascial membrane”)—described by Rohrich et al 19 and discussed by others 20,21 —directly or indirectly helped maintain the position of the alar base. However, having rediscovered the structural integrity of tela subcutanea cutis, Daniel et al understandably question the existence of any “ligaments” from the pyriform aperture to components of the alar lobule. Thus, for example, it is conceivable that there are actually other structures (eg, the modiolus alae nasi or the myrtiformus muscle) that may be tethering the ala to the pyriform aperture. The authors provide a superb demonstration (main article, Figures 5b and 7b) showing that these 2 structures are close to the pyriform aperture where the alar release maneuver is typically performed. 17 Whatever structures are involved, there is no doubt, clinically, that alar release is essential to achieving long-term nasal base width reduction. Future studies from the authors will assuredly bring the academic issue into clearer focus.

caption.p: Structures such as the modiolus alae nasi and myrtiformus muscle are near the pyriform aperture. It is reasonable, therefore, for the authors to question the existence of an actual “ligament” holding the ala in its position. (A, B) Clinically, when nasal base reduction is desired and an instrument is used to sweep tissues off the pyriform aperture, there is little doubt that tension is relieved. (C) This allows medialization of the alae so that an interalar (“cinch”) suture can be applied with much less chance of postoperative recurrence of the broad nasal base. Figure 2B was previously published in Gruber RP, Freeman MB, Hsu C, Elyassnia D, Reddy V. Nasal base reduction by alar release: a laboratory evaluation. Plast Reconstr Surg. 2009;123(2):709-715. Reprinted with permission.

body.p: Overall, the morphological and anatomical description of the lower nasal base provided by the authors is perhaps the clearest and most comprehensive that we have seen. Their analysis forces us to focus on a neglected region of the nose and provides several clinical implications that we look forward to implementing.
